qas.question: How does secure boot help avert boot process infections?

answers.text: uses a public-key infrastructure to verify the integrity of the operating system

qas.question: What requirements do Microsoft certified devices have?

answers.text: must have secure boot enabled by default, and provide ways for users to disable or re-configure the feature

qas.question: What must always be enable in ARM-based Windows RT devices?

plausible_answers.text: uses a public-key infrastructure to verify the integrity of the operating system

qas.question: How doesn't secure boot help avert boot process infections?

plausible_answers.text: uses a public-key infrastructure to verify the integrity of the operating system

qas.question: How does insecure boot help avert boot process infections?

plausible_answers.text: must have secure boot enabled by default, and provide ways for users to disable or re-configure the feature

qas.question: What requirements don't Microsoft certified devices have?

plausible_answers.text: must have secure boot enabled by default, and provide ways for users to disable or re-configure the feature

qas.question: What requirements do Microsoft uncertified devices have?
What must always be enable in ARM-based Windows TR devices?

context: Windows 8 supports a feature of the UEFI specification known as "Secure boot", which <a0_0><b3_0><b4_0>uses a public-key infrastructure to verify the integrity of the operating system<b4_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> and prevent unauthorized programs such as bootkits from infecting the device's boot process. Some pre-built devices may be described as "certified" by Microsoft; these <a1_0><b5_0><b6_0>must have secure boot enabled by default, and provide ways for users to disable or re-configure the feature<b6_0/><b5_0/><a1_0/>. ARM-based Windows RT devices must have <a2_0><b7_0>secure boot<b7_0/><a2_0/> permanently enabled.
